column1: # DO NOT EDIT THIS FILE MANUALLY. IT WAS GENERATED BY ETL step 'climate/latest/climate_change#climate-change'.

column2: Explore the impacts of global climate change.

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column12: Global warming: monthly sea surface temperature anomaly
column18: This is measured at a nominal depth of 20cm, and given relative to the average temperature from the period of 1961 - 1990.

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column12: Global warming: heat content in the top 700 meters of the world's oceans
column18: Ocean heat content is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference. It is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, 10²² joules are equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.
column19: Heat content is shown for four sources: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO); Institute of Atmospheric Physics (IAP); National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA); and Meteorological Research Institute (MRI).

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column12: Global warming: heat content in the top 2,000 meters of the world's oceans
column18: Ocean heat content is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference. It is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, 10²² joules are equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.
column19: Heat content is shown for four sources: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO); Institute of Atmospheric Physics (IAP); National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA); and Meteorological Research Institute (MRI).

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column18: Mean seawater pH is shown based on in-situ measurements of pH from the Aloha station in Hawaii.

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column18: Global mean sea level rise is measured relative to the 1993 - 2008 average sea level. This is shown as three series: the widely-cited Church & White dataset; the University of Hawaii Sea Level Center (UHLSC); and the average of the two.

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column12: Climate change: Arctic sea ice extent
column18: The minimum and maximum sea ice extent typically occur in February and September each year.

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column12: Climate change: Antarctic sea ice extent
column18: The minimum and maximum sea ice extent typically occur in February and September each year.

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column12: Climate change: change in mass of ice sheets
column18: Cumulative change in mass of ice sheets, measured relative to a base year of 2002. For reference, 1,000 billion metric tons is equal to about 260 cubic miles of ice—enough to raise sea level by about 3 millimeters.
column19: Combined measurements are based on more than 20 different studies that have been combined for each region.

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column12: Climate change: change of mass of US glaciers
column18: Cumulative mass balance of U.S. reference glaciers, relative to the base year 1965. This is given in meters of water equivalent, which represent changes in the average thickness of a glacier.

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column18: This metric measures the area covered by snow, based on an analysis of weekly maps. These data cover all of North America (including Greenland).

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column18: Atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO₂) concentration is measured in parts per million (ppm).

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column18: Atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO₂) concentration is measured in parts per million (ppm). Long-term trends in CO₂ concentrations can be measured at high-resolution using preserved air samples from ice cores.

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column18: Atmospheric methane (CH₄) concentration is measured in parts per billion (ppb).

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column18: Atmospheric methane (CH₄) concentration is measured in parts per billion (ppb).

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column18: Atmospheric nitrous oxide (N₂O) concentration is measured in parts per billion (ppb).

column11: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
column18: Atmospheric nitrous oxide (N₂O) concentration is measured in parts per billion (ppb).
